title: Robert Cornewall
text:
Robert Cornewall (1647–1705) of <a href="Berrington%20Hall">Berrington Hall</a>, Herefordshire, was an English soldier and courtier.
Life.
He was born in 1647, the eldest son of <a href="Humphrey%20Cornewall">Humphrey Cornewall</a> and Theophila Skynner, and was baptised at <a href="Eye%2C%20Herefordshire">Eye, Herefordshire</a>, on 17 June 1647.
He joined the <a href="British%20Army">army</a>, becoming an <a href="Ensign%20%28rank%29">Ensign</a> in <a href="Henry%20Somerset%2C%201st%20Duke%20of%20Beaufort">Lord Worcester</a>'s regiment on 13 June 1667, and a <a href="Captain%20%28armed%20forces%29">Captain</a> in <a href="John%20Talbot%20of%20Lacock">Sir John Talbot</a>'s Dragoons on 22 February 1678. He was made captain of an independent <a href="troop">troop</a> on 18 June 1685, <a href="Captain%20lieutenant">Captain lieutenant</a> in the <a href="Carabiniers%20%286th%20Dragoon%20Guards%29">Queen Dowager's Horse</a> on 31 July 1685, and captain in 1687.
He was elected to represent <a href="Leominster%20%28UK%20Parliament%20constituency%29">Leominster</a> in the <a href="1685%20English%20general%20election">general election of 1685</a>, a post that his father had occupied previously. He was also a <a href="Magistrate%20%28England%20and%20Wales%29">magistrate</a> in <a href="Herefordshire">Herefordshire</a> between 1675 and 1689; Commissioner for Assessment from 1677 to 1680 and in 1689; a <a href="Freedom%20of%20the%20City">freeman</a> of <a href="Ludlow">Ludlow</a> in 1681 and captain of the Herefordshire <a href="Militia">Militia</a> from 1683 to 1689. He was gentleman waiter to <a href="Prince%20George%20of%20Denmark">Prince George of Denmark</a> from 1683 to 1689.
Identified as a <a href="Jacobitism">Jacobite</a> after the <a href="Glorious%20Revolution">Glorious Revolution</a>, he lost his commission and his court appointments. An attempt to return to public life on the accession of <a href="Anne%2C%20Queen%20of%20Great%20Britain">Queen Anne</a> was unsuccessful.
Robert Cornewall died suddenly and was buried at Eye on 9 November 1705.
Family.
Cornewall married Edith Cornewallis, daughter of Sir Francis Cornewallis of Abermarlais, <a href="Carmarthenshire">Carmarthenshire</a>, in July 1668. The couple had eleven children:
